user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_MD5_update:
```c
void
MHD_MD5_update (struct Md5Ctx *ctx,
                const uint8_t *data,
                size_t length)
{
  unsigned int bytes_have; /**< Number of bytes in the context buffer */

  mhd_assert ((data != NULL) || (length == 0));

#ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  if (0 == length)
    return; /* Shortcut, do nothing */
#endif /* MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */

  /* Note: (count & (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE-1))
           equals (count % MD5_BLOCK_SIZE) for this block size. */
  bytes_have = (unsigned int) (ctx->count & (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE - 1));
  ctx->count += length;

  if (0 != bytes_have)
  {
    unsigned int bytes_left = MD5_BLOCK_SIZE - bytes_have;
    if (length >= bytes_left)
    {     /* Combine new data with data in the buffer and
             process the full block. */
      memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have,
              data,
              bytes_left);
      data += bytes_left;
      length -= bytes_left;
      md5_transform (ctx->H, ctx->buffer);
      bytes_have = 0;
    }
  }

  while (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE <= length)
  {   /* Process any full blocks of new data directly,
         without copying to the buffer. */
    md5_transform (ctx->H, data);
    data += MD5_BLOCK_SIZE;
    length -= MD5_BLOCK_SIZE;
  }

  if (0 != length)
  {   /* Copy incomplete block of new data (if any)
         to the buffer. */
    memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have, data, length);
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (length >= bytes_left)
    {     /* Combine new data with data in the buffer and
             process the full block. */
      memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have,
              data,
              bytes_left);
      data += bytes_left;
      length -= bytes_left;
      md5_transform (ctx->H, ctx->buffer);
      bytes_have = 0;
    }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment: bytes_have is (ctx->count & (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE-1)) so 0 <= bytes_have <= MD5_BLOCK_SIZE-1. bytes_left is MD5_BLOCK_SIZE - bytes_have, therefore copying bytes_left bytes starting at offset bytes_have writes exactly up to index MD5_BLOCK_SIZE-1 of ctx->buffer (i.e. within an MD5_BLOCK_SIZE-sized buffer). The branch if (length >= bytes_left) guarantees the source data buffer has at least bytes_left bytes, and the earlier assert/early-return ensures data is non-NULL when length > 0. Thus, assuming ctx->buffer is an array of size MD5_BLOCK_SIZE (as required by the MD5 context), the memcpy does not access beyond the bounds of either operand. A violation would occur only if the Md5Ctx::buffer is smaller than MD5_BLOCK_SIZE or ctx->count is corrupted.
